list.title: Question 2
list.content: Letf(x)=x3f(x) = x^3f(x)=x3andg(x)=2x−1g(x) = 2x - 1g(x)=2x−1, forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.Findg−1(x)g^{-1}(x)g−1(x).[2]Find(g∘f)(x)(g\circ f)(x)(g∘f)(x).[2]Solve the equation(g∘f)(x)=0(g\circ f)(x) = 0(g∘f)(x)=0.[2]
list.markScheme:
If we solve the equation(g∘g−1)(x)=x(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x(g∘g−1)(x)=xfory=g−1(x)y = g^{-1}(x)y=g−1(x), we getg(g−1(x))=xg(y)=x2y−1=x2y=x+1y=x+12\begin{aligned}
g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]
g(y) &= x \\[12pt]
2y - 1 &= x \\[12pt]
2y &= x + 1 \\[6pt]
y &= \dfrac{x + 1}{2} \hspace{1.9em} \\
\end{aligned}g(g−1(x))g(y)2y−12yy​=x=x=x=x+1=2x+1​​g−1(x)=x+12\answer{g^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x+1}{2}} \hspace{0.6em}g−1(x)=2x+1​​We have(g∘f)(x)=g(f(x))=g(x3)=2x3−1\begin{aligned}
(g\circ f)(x) &= g(f(x)) \\[6pt]
&= g(x^3) \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 2x^3-1} \hspace{1.1em}\end{aligned}(g∘f)(x)​=g(f(x))=g(x3)=2x3−1​​Solving the equation(g∘f)(x)=0(g\circ f)(x) = 0(g∘f)(x)=0forxxx, we obtain2x3−1=0[by part (b)]\begin{aligned}
\hspace{5.5em} 2x^3-1 &= 0 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (b)}] \\
\end{aligned}2x3−1​=0[by part (b)]​x≈0.794[by using G.D.C.]\hspace{12.2em} \answer{x \approx 0.794} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]x≈0.794​[by using G.D.C.]

list.title: Question 3
list.content: Letf(x)=x2+2f(x) = x^2 + 2f(x)=x2+2andg(x)=x−3g(x) = x - 3g(x)=x−3, forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.Findf(3)f(3)f(3).[2]Find(g∘f)(3)(g\circ f)(3)(g∘f)(3).[2]Findg−1(x)g^{-1}(x)g−1(x).[2]
list.markScheme:
Evaluatingf(x)=x2+2f(x) = x^2 + 2f(x)=x2+2forx=3x = 3x=3, we getf(3)=32+2=9+2=11\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.6em} f(3) &= 3^2 + 2 \\[6pt]
&= 9 + 2 \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 11}\end{aligned}f(3)​=32+2=9+2=11​​Evaluating(g∘f)(x)=g(f(x))(g\circ f)(x) = g(f(x))(g∘f)(x)=g(f(x))forx=3x = 3x=3, we obtain(g∘f)(3)=g(f(3))=g(11)[by part (a)]=11−3=8\begin{aligned}
\hspace{6.4em} (g\circ f)(3) &= g(f(3)) \\[6pt]
&= g(11) \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[6pt]
&= 11 - 3 \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 8}\end{aligned}(g∘f)(3)​=g(f(3))=g(11)[by part (a)]=11−3=8​​If we solve the equation(g∘g−1)(x)=x(g\circ g^{-1})(x) = x(g∘g−1)(x)=xfory=g−1(x)y = g^{-1}(x)y=g−1(x), we findg(g−1(x))=xg(y)=xy−3=xy=x+3\begin{aligned}
g(g^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[6pt]
g(y) &= x \\[6pt]
y - 3 &= x \\[6pt]
y &= x + 3 \hspace{2.1em} \\
\end{aligned}g(g−1(x))g(y)y−3y​=x=x=x=x+3​g−1(x)=x+3\answer{g^{-1}(x) = x+3} \hspace{0.8em}g−1(x)=x+3​

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Letf(x)=4x−3f(x) = 4x - 3f(x)=4x−3andg(x)=2xg(x) = 2xg(x)=2x, forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.Write down the value ofg(5)g(5)g(5).[1]Find(f∘g)(x)(f\circ g)(x)(f∘g)(x).[2]Find(f∘g)−1(x)(f\circ g)^{-1}(x)(f∘g)−1(x).[2]
list.markScheme:
g(5)=10\answer{g(5) = 10}g(5)=10​We have(f∘g)(x)=f(g(x))=f(2x)=4(2x)−3=8x−3\begin{aligned}
(f\circ g)(x) &= f(g(x)) \\[6pt]
&= f(2x) \\[6pt]

&\answer{= 8x - 3}\end{aligned}(f∘g)(x)​=f(g(x))=f(2x)=4(2x)−3=8x−3​​Leth(x)=(f∘g)(x)h(x) = (f\circ g)(x)h(x)=(f∘g)(x).
Henceh−1(x)=(f∘g)−1(x)h^{-1}(x) = (f\circ g)^{-1}(x)h−1(x)=(f∘g)−1(x).If we solve the equation(h∘h−1)(x)=x(h\circ h^{-1})(x) = x(h∘h−1)(x)=xfory=h−1(x)y = h^{-1}(x)y=h−1(x), we geth(h−1(x))=xh(y)=x8y−3=x8y=x+3y=x+38\begin{aligned}
h(h^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]
h(y) &= x \\[12pt]
8y - 3 &= x \\[12pt]
8y &= x + 3 \\[6pt]
y &= \dfrac{x + 3}{8} \hspace{1.8em} \\
\end{aligned}h(h−1(x))h(y)8y−38yy​=x=x=x=x+3=8x+3​​(f∘g)−1(x)=x+38\answer{(f\circ g)^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x + 3}{8}} \hspace{2.7em}(f∘g)−1(x)=8x+3​​

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Letf(x)=2xf(x) = 2xf(x)=2x,g(x)=4x+6g(x) = 4x + 6g(x)=4x+6andh(x)=(f∘g)(x)h(x) = (f\circ g)(x)h(x)=(f∘g)(x), forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.Findh(x)h(x)h(x).[2]Findh−1(x)h^{-1}(x)h−1(x).[3]
list.markScheme:
We haveh(x)=(f∘g)(x)=f(g(x))=f(4x+6)=2(4x+6)=8x+12\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.3em} h(x) &= (f\circ g)(x) \\[6pt]
&= f(g(x)) \\[6pt]
&= f(4x+6) \\[6pt]
&= 2(4x+6) \\[6pt]
&\answer{= 8x+12}\end{aligned}h(x)​=(f∘g)(x)=f(g(x))=f(4x+6)=2(4x+6)=8x+12​​If we solve the equation(h∘h−1)(x)=x(h\circ h^{-1})(x) = x(h∘h−1)(x)=xfory=h−1(x)y = h^{-1}(x)y=h−1(x), we geth(h−1(x))=xh(y)=x8y+12=x8y=x−12y=x−128\begin{aligned}
h(h^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[12pt]
h(y) &= x \\[12pt]
8y+12 &= x \\[12pt]
8y &= x-12 \\[6pt]
y &= \dfrac{x-12}{8} \hspace{1.3em} \\
\end{aligned}h(h−1(x))h(y)8y+128yy​=x=x=x=x−12=8x−12​​h−1(x)=x−128\answer{h^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{x-12}{8}}h−1(x)=8x−12​​

list.title: Question 11
list.content: The equation of a lineL1L_1L1​is2x+3y=−52x + 3y = -52x+3y=−5.Find the gradient ofL1L_1L1​.[2]A second line,L2L_2L2​, is perpendicular toL1L_1L1​.State the gradient ofL2L_2L2​.[1]The point P(4,0)(4,0)(4,0)lies onL2L_2L2​.Find the equation ofL2L_2L2​, giving your answer in the formax+by+d=0ax + by + d = 0ax+by+d=0, wherea,b,d∈Za, b, d \in \mathbb{Z}a,b,d∈Z.[2]The point Q is the intersection ofL1L_1L1​andL2L_2L2​.Find the coordinates of Q.[3]
list.markScheme:
If we rewrite the equation ofL1L_1L1​in the formy=mx+cy = mx + cy=mx+c, we
have2x+3y=−53y=−2x−5y=−23x−53\begin{aligned}
2x + 3y &= -5 \\[12pt]
3y &= -2x - 5 \\[6pt]
y &= -\dfrac{2}{3}x-\dfrac{5}{3} \hspace{0.4em} \\
\end{aligned}2x+3y3yy​=−5=−2x−5=−32​x−35​​Hence the gradient ofL1L_1L1​ismL1=−23\answer{m_{L_1} = -\dfrac{2}{3}}mL1​​=−32​​The gradient ofL2L_2L2​ismL2=−1mL1[sinceL2⊥L1]=−1(−2/3)=32\begin{aligned}
\hspace{9em} m_{L_2} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $L_2 \perp L_1$}] \\[6pt]
&= -\dfrac{1}{(-2/3)} \\[6pt]
&\answer{= \dfrac{3}{2}}\end{aligned}mL2​​​=−mL1​​1​[sinceL2​⊥L1​]=−(−2/3)1​=23​​​Using the point-gradient formula with P(4,0)(4,0)(4,0)andm=3/2m = 3/2m=3/2, we gety−y1=m(x−x1)y−0=32(x−4)2y=3x−12\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.2em} y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[5pt]
y - 0 &= \dfrac{3}{2}\hspace{0.05em}(x - 4) \\[6pt]
2y &= 3x - 12 \\
\end{aligned}y−y1​y−02y​=m(x−x1​)=23​(x−4)=3x−12​0=3x−2y−12\hspace{3.45em} \answer{0 = 3x - 2y - 12}0=3x−2y−12​We haveL1:2x+3y=−5(1)L2:3x−2y=12(2)\begin{aligned}
L_1&:\hspace{1.0em} 2x + 3y = -5 \hspace{3em}{(1)} \\[6pt]
L_2&:\hspace{1.0em} 3x - 2y = 12 \hspace{3.25em}{(2)}\end{aligned}L1​L2​​:2x+3y=−5(1):3x−2y=12(2)​Solving
the system of linear equations(1)(1)(1)-(2)(2)(2)forxxxandyyy, we
obtainx=2y=−3\begin{aligned}

\hspace{-0.8em} \begin{array}{rcl}
x &=& 2 \\[6pt]
y &=& -3
\end{array}\end{aligned}xy​==​2−3​​Hence the coordinates of Q are(2,−3)\answer{(2,-3)}(2,−3)​

list.content: Letf(x)=(x+2)3f(x) = (x+2)^3f(x)=(x+2)3, forx∈Rx \in \mathbb{R}x∈R.Findf−1(x)f^{-1}(x)f−1(x).[3]Letgggbe a function so that(f∘g)(x)=27x6(f\circ g)(x) = 27x^6(f∘g)(x)=27x6.Findg(x)g(x)g(x).[3]
list.markScheme:
If we solve the equation(f∘f−1)(x)=x(f\circ f^{-1})(x) = x(f∘f−1)(x)=xfory=f−1(x)y = f^{-1}(x)y=f−1(x), we getf(f−1(x))=xf(y)=x(y+2)3=xy+2=x3y=x3−2\begin{aligned}
f(f^{-1}(x)) &= x \\[7pt]
f(y) &= x \\[6pt]
(y+2)^3 &= x \\[6pt]
y+2 &= \sqrt[3]{x} \\[6pt]
y &= \sqrt[3]{x} - 2 \hspace{1.1em} \\
\end{aligned}f(f−1(x))f(y)(y+2)3y+2y​=x=x=x=3x​=3x​−2​f−1(x)=x3−2\hspace{0.3em} \answer{f^{-1}(x) = \sqrt[3]{x} - 2}f−1(x)=3x​−2​If we solve the equation(f∘g)(x)=27x6(f\circ g)(x) = 27x^6(f∘g)(x)=27x6fory=g(x)y = g(x)y=g(x), we
obtainf(g(x))=27x6f(y)=27x6(y+2)3=27x6y+2=3x2y=3x2−2\begin{aligned}
f(g(x)) &= 27x^6 \\[6pt]

list.content:
The ocean pressure,PPP, under sea level can be modelled by the functionP(D)=D10+1P(D) = \dfrac{D}{10}+1P(D)=10D​+1whereDDDis the distance in metres below sea
level andPPPis measured in atmospheres.A submarine cruising near the surface is submerged according to the
functionD(t)=10+5tD(t) = 10+5tD(t)=10+5twheretttis measured in minutes andDDDis
the distance the submarine is below sea level, measured in
metres.Find the composite functionP∘DP\circ DP∘Dand explain what it means in
thecontext of this question[3]Find and interpret(P∘D)(10)(P\circ D)(10)(P∘D)(10).[2]
list.markScheme:
The composite function can be expressed as(P∘D)(t)=P(D(t))=P(10+5t)=10+5t10+1=2+t2(1)\begin{aligned}
(P\circ D) (t) &= P(D(t)) \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
&= P(10+5t)\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
&= \dfrac{10+5t}{10}+1 \rule[-4.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
&\hspace{0.28em}\answer{= 2+\dfrac{t}{2}}\rule[-5.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\hspace{6em}{(1)}\end{aligned}(P∘D)(t)​=P(D(t))=P(10+5t)=1010+5t​+1=2+2t​​(1)​This composite function represents the ocean pressure (in atmospheres) outside the submarine at timetminutes.\answer{\text{This composite function represents the ocean pressure (in atmospheres) outside the submarine at time $t$ minutes.}}This composite function represents the ocean pressure (in atmospheres) outside the submarine at timetminutes.​Substitutingt=10t=10t=10in (1), we get(P∘D)(10)=2+102=7\begin{aligned}
(P\circ D)(10)&=2+\dfrac{10}{2}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
&\hspace{0.28em}\answer{=7}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\end{aligned}(P∘D)(10)​=2+210​=7​​This result means that after 10 minutes, the ocean pressure outside the submarine is 7 atmospheres.\answer{\text{This result means that after 10 minutes, the ocean pressure outside the submarine is 7 atmospheres.}}This result means that after 10 minutes, the ocean pressure outside the submarine is 7 atmospheres.​

\end{aligned}N(6)​=3(6)−9=9​Thus, the profit is given by P(9)P(9)=60(9)−850=−310\begin{aligned}
 P(9) &= 60(9)-850 = -310

&= P(3t-9) \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\
&= 60(3t-9)-850\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{7mm}\\
&\hspace{-5em}\answer{(P\circ N)(t) = 180\hspace{0.05em}t-1390}\hspace{5em}{(1)}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{4mm}\end{aligned}(P∘N)(t)​=P(N(t))=P(3t−9)=60(3t−9)−850(P∘N)(t)=180t−1390​(1)​The company has a positive profit if (1) is greater than 0. Hence(P∘N)(t)>0180t−1390>0t>1390180t>7.72.\begin{aligned}
(P\circ N)(t) &>0\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
180t-1390 &> 0 \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
t &> \dfrac{1390}{180} \rule[-3mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
t &> 7.72.\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}(P∘N)(t)180t−1390tt​>0>0>1801390​>7.72.​Therefore, the
factory needs to operate8\answer{8}8​hours per day in order for the company to earn a positive profit.

\answer{\text{Range: } 200\leq P(x) \leq 200+70\pi.}\\

the variablesxxxandyyyand rearrange foryyy, as followsy=200+2πxx=200+2πyy=x−2002πP−1(x)=12πx−100π\begin{aligned}

&\hspace{-3.2em}\answer{P^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{1}{2\pi}x - \dfrac{100}{\pi}}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}yxy​=200+2πx=200+2πy=2πx−200​P−1(x)=2π1​x−π100​​​For each of the proposed perimetersPPP, we can find the radius
